p.s: Each olfactory cortical hemisphere receives ipsilateral odor 1 information directly from the olfactory bulb and contralateral 2 information indirectly from the other cortical hemisphere.
Since 3 neural projections to the olfactory cortex are disordered and non-4 topographic, spatial information cannot be used to align projections 5 from the two sides like in the visual cortex.
Therefore, how bilateral 6 information is integrated in individual cortical neurons is unknown.

7 We have found, in mice, that the odor responses of individual 8 neurons to selective stimulation of each of the two nostrils are 9 highly matched, such that odor identity decoding optimized with 10 information arriving from one nostril transfers very well to the other 11 side.
Remarkably, these aligned responses are nevertheless 12 asymmetric enough to allow decoding of stimulus laterality.
13 Computational analysis shows that such matched odor tuning is 14 incompatible with purely random connections but is explained 15 readily by Hebbian plasticity structuring bilateral connectivity.
Our 16 data reveal that despite the distributed and fragmented sensory 17 representation in the olfactory cortex, odor information across the 18 two hemispheres is highly coordinated.

In senses such as vision and audition, information from paired sensors 22 (eyes or ears) is combined in the brain to perform specific 23 computations that are behaviorally relevant -for example, estimating 24 distance to or the direction of the source of the stimuli (Cumming and 25 DeAngelis, 2001;Grothe and Pecka, 2014).

The existence of two 26 sensors for olfaction has prompted hypotheses about their function 27 (Catania, 2013;Esquivelzeta Rabell et al., 2017;Mainland et al., 2002;28 Porter et al., 2005;Rajan et al., 2006).

Information from the two 29 nostrils can be differentiated, or integrated, depending on the goal of 30 such computation for the animal -for example, odor source 31 localization when smooth gradients exist (√Ålvarez-Salvado et al., 32 2018;Baker et al., 2018;Catania, 2013;Esquivelzeta Rabell et al., 33 2017;Gire et al., 2016), or identify relevant smells independent of the 34 odor source location or nostril stimulated (Bojsen-Moller and 35 Fahrenkrug, 1971;Dalal et al., 2020;Eccles, 2000;Kikuta et al., 2008;36 Kucharski andHall, 1987, 1988;Mainland et al., 2002).
These 37 computations will dictate the nature of the inter-hemispheric 38 communication and the mechanisms of integration of bilateral 39 olfactory cues.
Odors are detected by olfactory sensory neurons in the nose, which 41 project to the ipsilateral olfactory bulb (OB).

The OB sends 42 information to multiple ipsilateral brain regions, including the 43 anterior olfactory nucleus (AON) and the anterior and posterior 44 piriform cortices (APC and PPC, respectively) (Giessel and Datta, 2014;45 Mori et al., 1999;Nagayama et al., 2014;Wilson and Sullivan, 2011) 46 (Figure 1A) In many species, including rodents, the two nares are 47 separated by a septum that minimizes transfer of inhaled odors 48 between nostrils (Eccles, 2000;Kikuta et al., 2008;Wilson and 49 Sullivan, 1999).

Therefore, information transfer across hemispheres is 50 largely neural, and originates in the cortex (Bekkers and Suzuki, 2013;51 Boyd et al., 2012;Haberly and Price, 1978;Kikuta et al., 2008;Scott et 52 al., 1980;Wilson and Sullivan, 2011) (Figure 1A).

Bilateral cortical interactions have been investigated in other senses 54 including vision, where the brain forms ordered representations of 55 the world using topographic maps, which allow neural matching 56 through precise point-to-point mapping (Cang and Feldheim, 2013; 57 Gu and Cang, 2016;Luo and Flanagan, 2007).

However, the olfactory 58 cortex contains no recognizable topography (Bekkers and Suzuki,59 2013; Ghosh et al., 2011;Illig and Haberly, 2003;Miyamichi et al., 60 2011;Pashkovski et al., 2020;Sosulski et al., 2011;Stettler and Axel, 61 2009; Wilson and Sullivan, 2011), making point-to-point matching of 62 bilateral information through continuous maps implausible.

It is 63 possible that odor representations in the two primary olfactory cortex 64 hemispheres are essentially independent, and downstream areas 65 align them for coherent perception, as implicitly proposed by Schaffer 66 et al 2018. 67 Framing hypotheses about bilateral olfactory processing requires 68 basic information about how single cortical neurons respond to the 69 same odor presented to the two nostrils.

Such information is 70 fundamental for uncovering the computations performed, just as 71 details about binocular matching and disparity in cortical responses 72 were for vision (Blake and Wilson, 2011).
Individual neurons could 73 respond to ipsi-and contra-lateral odor stimuli in a congruent or 74 disparate manner.

There is some evidence for responses in olfactory 75 cortical areas to contralateral odor stimulation, but there is little 76 information on the alignment of ipsi-and contra-lateral responses 77 (Kikuta et al., 2008(Kikuta et al., , 2010;;Wilson, 1997).

Recent evidence suggests 78 that mitral cells in the OB may have matched responses through 79 organized feedback projections from the anterior olfactory nucleus 80 (AON) par externa (Grobman et al., 2018;Yan et al., 2008).
A cortical 81 neuron may then be able to inherit the matched response from mitral 82 cells (Dalal et al., 2020), but a direct evaluation of cortical matching is 83 lacking 84
To investigate how the olfactory cortex combines information from 85 the two nostrils, we recorded odor-evoked spiking activity of 86 individual neurons in the OC of awake mice.
We observed neuron 87 responses to selective odor stimulation through the contralateral 88 nostril in all cortical regions recorded.
A significant fraction of OC 89 neurons showed a strong match of ipsi-and contralateral response 90 profiles.
Population activity in OC could be used to accurately decode 91 odor identity, as well as side identity.
A computational model of the 92 olfactory system suggested that the bilateral overlap we observed in 1 mice is only possible with non-random bilateral projections.
Our 2 results provide fundamental and novel insight that defines how ipsi-3 and contralateral information streams converge and ultimately 4 enhance the processing capabilities of the brain.

A New Method for Unilateral Odor Delivery 8 A major goal of this study was to compare the bilateral odor receptive 9 fields of OC neurons of awake mice.
To do so, we needed a way to 10 reliably deliver odors to one nostril at a time.
Previous studies have 11 used two different techniques to achieve such unilateral odor 12 stimulations.
Either a piece of tubing was inserted in each nostril 13 (Wilson, 1997), or the two nostrils were separated by a plastic septum 14 (Kikuta et al., 2010(Kikuta et al., , 2008)).
Since mice have very sensitive muzzles, 15 neither of these approaches is applicable to awake animals.
16 We developed a new facial mask for unilateral odor delivery in awake 17 mice (Figure 1B).
On each side of the mask, close to the nostrils, we 18 used a computer-controlled olfactometer to deliver 15 19 monomolecular odors, one at the time, to the left or the right nostril 20
(Figures S1A-S1B).
The mask was connected to an airflow sensor for 21 respiration monitoring (Figures S1C-S1F).
We aligned all neuronal 22
odor-evoked activity to the first sniff after odor onset (see Methods).
We tested the side selectivity of the mask through two methods.

First,24 we simultaneously monitored the glomerular activity at the surface 25 of the OBs of OMP-GCaMP3 mice (Isogai et al., 2011) through calcium 26 imaging, while delivering odors to either nostril (Figure 1C) (n=155 27 glomeruli, 6 OBs, 3 mice).
When odors were presented on the 28 contralateral nostril, glomeruli showed little to no response (Figures 29 1D-1F).

We also performed extracellular recordings of mitral/tufted cells 31 (M/T) in the OB of awake mice using chronically implanted tetrodes 32 (n=42 single units isolated from 4 mice) (Figure 1G, S1G-S1J, and Table 33 S1).

M/T cells hardly responded to contralateral odor presentations: 34 out of the 42 isolated neurons, 32 responded to ipsilateral 35 stimulations, while 10 showed significant contralateral responses 36 (Figure 1H).
Furthermore, while the ipsilateral M/T cell responses 37 were largely positive, the few contralateral responses were always 38 negative (Figure 1H).

The ratio of contra to ipsilateral response magnitude elicited by odors 40 presented within the mask was 0.12 in our glomerular imaging data 41 (ŒîF/F magnitude, average ¬± SEM, ipsi: 7.9% ¬± 0.025%; contra: 0.93% 42 ¬± 7.0e-3%) (Figure 1I) and 0.10 in our M/T recordings (response 43 magnitude, average ¬± SEM, ipsi: 1.6Hz ¬± 0.019Hz; contra: 0.16Hz ¬± 44 2.1e-3Hz) (Figure 1J).
Therefore, on average, odor responses were 8 45 to 10 times stronger on the ipsilateral side of the mask, compared to 46 the contralateral side.
Previous work has indicated that M/T cell 47 responses to a given odor at a concentration of 0.1% were quite 48 similar to the same odor at a concentration of 1% (Bolding andFranks, 49 2018, 2017).

Since the M/T cell responses we observe are 50 substantially smaller for contralateral presentations, the effective 51 odor concentration in the ipsilateral nostril, when odors are 52 presented contralaterally, is likely to be much less than 10% of the 53 initial concentration from ipsilateral presentations.

Together, these results confirmed that odors, when delivered to one 55 nostril through our custom-built mask, activate sensory neurons in 56 the other nostril at least an order of magnitude less than ipsilateral activation.

div.head: Unilateral Odor Tuning of Different Regions of the Olfactory

p.s: We next used our unilateral odor delivery system to characterize how the OC responds to unilateral odor presentations.

To do so, we monitored the activity of the AON and APC through extracellular recordings in awake mice (n=7 mice, 1315 neurons total; AON: 3 mice, 384 neurons; APC: 4 mice, 931 neurons) (Figures 2A,S2, and Table S1).
Overall, neurons in the OC had low spontaneous activity (Figure 2B), in accordance with previous studies (Bolding and Franks, 2017;Litaudon et al., 2003;Zhan and Luo, 2010).
Spontaneous activity in the AON was significantly higher than in the APC (average spontaneous activity ¬± SEM, AON: 3.9Hz ¬± 0.012Hz; APC: 2.8Hz ¬± 3.6e-3Hz; rank-sum test, p<0.0001).

We found a diversity of responses to ipsi-as well as contralateral odor stimulation in both the AON and APC, including neurons that responded to odors presented to either one or the other nostril, or to both nostrils (Figures 2C-2D).

Importantly, in both OC regions, a sizeable fraction of neurons responded to contralateral odor presentations (fraction of neurons significantly responding to at least one odor presented on the ipsilateral nostril, AON: 86%; APC: 81%; contralateral side, AON: 87%; APC: 83%), expanding earlier anesthetized observations to the awake OC (Kikuta et al., 2008(Kikuta et al., , 2010;;Wilson, 1997).
OC neurons typically responded to at most a few odors from our odor panel (Figure 2E), as previously reported with bilateral odor stimulations (Bolding and Franks, 2017;Iurilli and Datta, 2017).

We found a wide range of response magnitudes across the OC, and contralateral responses were as strong as ipsilateral ones in the APC, and slightly weaker in the AON (Figure 2F; Wilcoxon signed-rank test, ipsi versus contra distribution, AON: p=8.2e-3;

An idiosyncratic feature of olfactory cortical responses is that a neuron that responds to a particular odor with an increase in firing rate, tends to exhibit increases in firing rates for any other odor it responds to; similarly, a neuron having inhibitory response to an odor is also inhibited by any other odor it responds to (Bolding and Franks, 2017;Hu et al., 2017;Kikuta et al., 2008;Otazu et al., 2015;Zhan and Luo, 2010).
We find that this 51 feature applies to both cortical regions we examined (Figure 2G).
52 Overall, we found reliable unilateral odor responses to both the ipsi- information, but it is unclear whether this information is similar to 58 that arriving ipsilaterally.
To examine this issue, we related the 59 average odor-evoked responses to ipsilateral against contralateral presentations.
First, we plotted the ipsi-versus contralateral odor responses for each neuron individually.
Given the prevalent view of OC connectivity as largely random, we expected OC neurons to show little to no match between their ipsi-and contralateral odor response profiles.

To our surprise, we found many neurons with bilaterally-correlated odor responses (Figure 3A) (F-test, significance of the linear model, from left to right neuron, top row: p=0.41; p=0.84; p=0.54; p=0.59; bottom row: p=5.3e-6; p=5.5e-4; p=6.6e-3; p=2.2e-4) (see also Figure 2D, neurons with an asterisk).
Overall, for each mouse recorded in the OC, we consistently found a sizeable fraction of bilaterally-correlated neurons (Figure 3B).
We used a bootstrap strategy to determine that the fraction of bilaterally-correlated neurons in each mouse was significantly higher than what one would expect from chance.
In brief, for each mouse, each neuron, we randomly shuffled odor identities on each nostril separately.
We repeated this shuffling for all neurons and calculated the resulting percentage of bilaterally-correlated neurons.
We reiterated this procedure 10,000 times in order to build a "chance" distribution.
Finally, we compared this distribution with the actual fraction of bilaterally-correlated neurons.
In all mice recorded in the OC, the fraction of bilaterally-correlated neurons was greater than one would expect from chance (Figures 3B,3C, and S3A-S3D).

While our initial estimates of the fraction of bilaterally-correlated neurons include all neurons recorded (Figures 3B,S3A), we verified that our conclusions remained true when selecting only the significantly responding (Figures S3B-S3C).
We performed additional analysis to determine the extent to which response variability masks response correlations.
We generated individual trials from a Poisson process with rates determined from our recordings.
We then enquired how correlated responses would be for two independent sets of 7 trials generated with the same set of data.

A large number of such sampling revealed that the fraction of (simulated) neurons that show significant response correlations was on the order of 40-80% even when the ideal response correlations should be 100% (Figure S3D).
This analysis indicates that the fraction of significantly correlated neurons in the AON observed in our recordings may underestimate the real fraction of bilaterallycorrelated neurons.
Overall, the bilateral correlations were strong (Figure 3D), with mostly positive slopes (Figure 3E), and a distribution of intercepts centered on zero (Figure 3F).

In other words, bilaterally-correlated neurons appear to respond to unilateral odor presentations in a mostly sideinvariant way, with their ipsi-and contralateral odor responses similar in sign and amplitude.
We wondered if the bilaterally matched responses occurred preferentially in a particular neuron type.

We used a classic method for identifying putative excitatory and inhibitory neurons -the width of extracellular action potentials (Frank et al., 2001;Gur et al., 1999;Hassani et al., 2009;Povysheva et al., 2006;Suzuki and Smith, 1985;59 Swadlow, 2003;Weir et al., 2015).
Most of the bilaterally-correlated 60 neurons in the AON and APC had broader spikes and lower 61 spontaneous activity (Figure S3E-S3H), suggesting they are excitatory.

Side 54 identity, or laterality, could indeed be decoded with high accuracy 55 (Figure 4D), which confirms that odor representations from both 56 sides, despite similarities, remain distinct and separable.

We then asked what type of structured interhemispheric connectivity 90 is sufficient to achieve the observed tight alignment of responses 91 from different nostrils.
Through computational modelling we tested a 92 simple and plausible model for structured matching, a Hebbian connectivity matrix that links together the same-odor representations in each hemisphere.

We combined this Hebbian matrix, (GStructured), with a random matrix, (GRandom), which models unstructured elements of connectivity and whose elements are drawn independently from a Gaussian distribution.
We vary the degree of structure using a parameter .

The parameter took values between 0 and 1 with = 0 corresponding to purely random connectivity and = 1 to purely structured connectivity.
The random and Hebbian components were scaled appropriately such that represents the proportion of contralateral input magnitude that is formed by structured connectivity.
Our modeling strategy began by creating a cortical representation of odors presented in the ipsilateral nostril, based on the AON.
Random OB-to-OC connectivity indicates that each cortical olfactory neuron samples a random subset of glomeruli.

This implies that the input to each cortical neuron is statistically independent, and that the response of one cortical neuron to different odorants can be modelled as a thresholded multivariate gaussian whose covariance matrix can be extracted from activities in the OB (Figure 6A, see Methods).
We validated this model of a single AON against neuronal recordings: our model replicated the population statistics remarkably well with minimal parameter adjustment (Figures 6B-6D; Figures S7A-S7C).

div.head: Importance of the Integration of Bilateral Information

p.s: 1 In many senses, information is collected through a pair of sensors and 2 is integrated within the brain.
Bilateral perception allows us to 3 perform vital behavioral computations such as sound localization or 4 depth perception.

Since the two nostrils may sample independent 5 pockets of air (Eccles, 2000;Kikuta et al., 2008;Wilson and Sullivan, 6 1999), can bilateral information be used to discover features of the 7 odor stimulus not readily available to single nostrils?

Animals may 8 compare of odor concentration across both nostrils to locate odor 9 sources (Catania, 2013;Esquivelzeta Rabell et al., 2017;Gire et al., 10 2016; Parthasarathy and Bhalla, 2013), which requires bilateral 11 integration and comparison of different signals.
Two brain regions 12 that seem to fulfil this criterion are the AON and APC (Kikuta et al., 13 2008(Kikuta et al., 13 , 2010;;Wilson, 1997).

Recent studies have indicated that the 14 AON may be sensitive to the differential activation of left and right 15 nostrils, therefore computing the direction of the stimulus in front of 16 the animal (Esquivelzeta Rabell et al., 2017).
Our own data shows that 17 side identity can be decoded from odor responses, which provides 18 further evidence for differential processing (Figure 4D).
In contrast, many behaviors require the animal to make inferences 20 independent of the nostril stimulated.
One simple example can be 21 found in our everyday life: one nostril is usually more blocked than 22 the other, and which nostril gets clogged changes several times a day 23 (Eccles, 2000).
Nevertheless, we can identify smells and have a unified 24 olfactory experience.
In the same fashion, animals need to be able to 25 identify relevant smells like food or a predator, no matter where the 26 odor source is relative to their nose.

Indeed, there is evidence for 27 nostril-independent recognition of odors: 28 rats trained to associate odors with reward 29 using only one naris can generalize to 30 stimuli delivered through the other nostril 31 (Kucharski andHall, 1988, 1987;Yan et al., 32 2008) S3J).
61 Third, recordings from putative M/T cells in the OB using tetrodes 62 revealed few detectable responses to contralateral nares stimulation.
These results seem at odds with a recent report suggesting that 64 topographic projections from contralateral AONpE to M/T cells 65 support bilaterally matched odor responses (Grobman et al., 2018).
A 66 possible source of the discrepancy is the much lower concentration 67 of odor used in our mask.
However our observations confirm former 68 work from various teams regarding the near absence of contralateral 69 M/T response in the OB (Kikuta et al., 2008(Kikuta et al., , 2010;;Wilson, 1997).

Our 70 results are also consistent with the known projections from the AON 71 pars externa to the GABAergic granule cells of the contralateral OB 72 (Schoenfeld and Macrides, 1984;Yan et al., 2008) 2).
This is not entirely surprising, since crossed projections 83 already occur at the level of the AON and APC.
Previous studies 84 indicated that contralateral stimulation evoked fewer and weaker 85 responses in the AON (Kikuta et al., 2008).
However, these studies 86 recorded from a small number of neurons in anesthetized animals.
While we confirmed the presence of weaker and fewer responses to contralateral stimulations in the AON, the differences were much smaller than previously reported.
Another recent study implicated AON in interhemispheric communication using a variety of methods, but the responses of neurons in this area were not measured (Yan et al., 2008).

Finally, one previous study reported the presence of neurons responsive to contralateral naris stimulations in the APC of anesthetized rats, but did not test the correlation of the responses between the two nares (Wilson, 1997).
We found that the odor information arriving ipsilaterally to the OC strongly matches that arriving contralaterally (Figure 3).

Our control experiments indicated that less than 10% of an odor delivered to one nostril may leak to the other nostril, and we found that this potential 10% leak is not sufficient to explain the presence of bilateral neurons.
Furthermore, our data offer strong hints that principal neurons are a major part of the ensemble of neurons that have matched responses to stimuli from both nostrils (Figure S3).
This feature would allow downstream areas receiving olfactory cortical inputs to readily have access to side-stable odor responses.
Indeed, we showed explicitly that odor decoding is transferrable across sides (Figure 4), as expected from the presence of matched responses in the OC.
Finally, we considered how the prevalent view of OC connectivity could explain our data (Figure 5).
Recent studies have shown that two representations projected through the same random matrix remain correlated (Babadi and Sompolinsky, 2014;Schaffer et al., 2018).

In addition, another study reported that population response correlations between odors is shaped in the cortex, presumably by experience, such that some response similarities in the OB are enhanced and others are suppressed (Pashkovski et al., 2020).
However, these studies do not address alignment due to projections between cortices.
Here we implemented a computational model of the olfactory system to test matching of ipsilateral and contralateral odor tuning in the OC as a function of structure in bilateral projections.
We showed that, in our model, purely random projections cannot explain our OC results.
That is, even if the two hemispheres have the same ordered representations for similar odors, unstructured interhemispheric cortical projections will disrupt these correlations.

div.head: Reconciling Our Results with Known Connectivity Schemes

p.s: How can the responses of cortical neurons to selective stimulation of each of the two nostrils be matched?
First, there may be topographically matched crossed projection somewhere in the olfactory system allowing bilateral response matching.
The only known candidate for such matching is the projection from AON pars externa to OB (Schoenfeld and Macrides, 1984;Yan et al., 2008).

This projection, however, should result in net inhibition of M/T cells since its major target are the GABAergic granule cells (Schoenfeld and Macrides, 1984;Yan et al., 2008) (but see Grobman et al., 2018).

Furthermore, previous studies (Kikuta et al., 2010(Kikuta et al., , 2008;;Wilson, 1997) and our own data (Figure 1) suggest that this projection is too weak to support the widespread bilateral matching we observed in the OC.

However, M/T cells that respond to contralateral odor presentation in a correlated way (Grobman et al 2018) may report to ipsilateral OC neurons the same information for ipsi-and contralateral stimulation under some conditions, for example, high odor concentrations.
Even so, unstructured interhemispheric cortical projections will disrupt this potential alignment in the cortex.
Therefore, additional mechanisms, such as Hebbian plasticity, are needed to explain our observations.

A second way in which matched responses may arise is through fine-62 scale order in anatomical connectivity that somehow allows the same 63 glomerular output channels from both OBs to converge on individual 64 neurons.
Such structure seems implausible and has no precedent but 65 remains formally possible.
66 A third explanation that seems likely because of its simplicity and local 67 nature is that synaptic connectivity in cortical regions is refined by 68

Odor identity decoding ability was assessed using linear classifiers and leave-out cross validation on a pseudopopulation made up of all neurons recorded in a particular cortical area -AON or APC (Bolding and Franks, 2017).
At each instance we chose a particular dataset (either ipsilateral or contralateral odor presentation) and formed from it a training set by randomly removing one trial per odor.
We calculated mean responses for each odor by averaging across the training set.
We then chose our test set in two related ways.
If we were testing on the same side as we trained (e.g., train ipsilaterally, test ipsilaterally), then the 15 trials (one per odor) outside the training set were used as the test set.
If we were testing on the opposite side (e.g., train ipsilaterally, test contralaterally), then one trial per odor from the opposite side was randomly chosen to form the test set.
Classification accuracy was measured by assigning each test trial to the closest Euclidean mean odor response and calculating the percentage of trials correctly assigned (Bolding and Franks, 2017).
This process was repeated 200 times using different random test and train trial choices.

In order to examine the effect of changing number of neurons on classification accuracy, we randomly selected neurons from the pseudopopulation and performed classification using only the selected cells.
This process is repeated 200 times.
We then report the average accuracy and standard deviation over those 200 selections of neurons and, for each set of neurons, 200 sets of train/test trials in Figures 4 andS5.
A very similar process is employed for side decoding.
One trial per side was removed, the remaining trials are averaged to form a mean side response for both ipsilateral and contralateral presentations.
The removed trials are then classified to the nearer mean side response and accuracy is the percentage correctly assigned.
This is repeated 200 times for different random removed trial choices.
Our model predicts the trial-averaged neural responses.
